column2: In the last part of this set of quests, you'll put together all the elements you've used so far to get things crazy!
Welcome back, {{user_name}}! Are you ready to put on a real light show? I know I am!

First things first - let's get back to the p5.js code editor. You can load your previous sketch (if you saved it at http://editor.p5js.org ), or get back to where we left off with this one: https://editor.p5js.org/madetohack/sketches/HNfYgEbV

Last time, we created something pretty cool, but it had 2 problems. First, it only used circles. Second, the circles got ‘stuck’ on a color sometimes. Let’s fix both of those problems and make a more impressive sound painter!
First, let’s fix the problem of the color “sticking”. In your first if statement, the one dealing with volume > 0.1, let’s add a new line just above the circle(... line: fill(255, 255, 255)
That line will 'reset' the color when the volume is greater than 0.1 but less than 0.2. Next, let’s change what happens when the volume is greater than 0.2
In the if statement that handles when volume is above 0.2, delete the line that says circle(...

Let’s replace that with: line(random(width), random(height), random(width), random(height)); We need to have 2 groups of randoms because a line gets drawn from one point to a second point – and we need to create both points, instead of just one for the circle.
If you run the code now, you should get some lines… but they won’t be very colorful. That’s because lines don’t care about fill(), they need a different function to color them.
Fortunately, it’s easy to fix that – on the line above line(..., change fill to stroke. If you run the code again, you’ll see the lines are now a different color!
If you’d like the lines to be thicker, you can make a new line above the one with stroke(... on it, and type strokeWeight(7) on it.

Awesome! Run your code and watch it go! Tweak the values in your code if you want to change things up – Maybe you want the if statements to cover different volume ranges, or the strokeWeight() to be higher or lower… or maybe you want every circle to be a different color!
Whatever you choose, you’re going to have something pretty cool to show your friends. Happy Hacking!
